kR1buRTIKhk.summary_all: In this video, the speaker provides 20 tips and tricks for climbers, including analyzing technique, taking care of skin, trying out different techniques, finding a shoe that fits well, and climbing frequently. They also emphasize the importance of not being intimidated by grades and trying difficult challenges. The speaker acknowledges the personal nature of training and encourages experimentation to find what works best for each individual. They also highlight the issue of eating disorders in climbing and encourage support for those struggling with them. The speaker asks for feedback and suggests that they may do more videos on tips and tricks.

summary_sections.text:
so it's been a while since i made one of these 
tutorial videos in this video i'm gonna teach you   hopefully uh 20 tricks that you didn't know that 
any climbers should know i guess so it's going   to be i'm going to go through them really quickly 
if you guys have any like if you want me to go in   depth on some of them please comment below maybe 
i can make a like a specific video on a specific   uh subject it's 20 tips and tricks so that's 
kind of a lot um so i'm just going to jump in   the first tip is back in the days 20 years 
ago when i started climbing this was only   for the professionals i remember 
all the professionals used a camera   a film camera not like this this is an iphone but 
uh like a big chunky camera to study the technique   nowadays we all have a cell phone and i 
think filming yourself is not only good for   posting on instagram or on youtube 
but also to analyze your technique   trying to figure out what you can do better and i 
think a lot of you if you haven't filmed yourself   climbing it's often like completely different from 
how you you think you're climbing uh the next step   is to clean your shoes from chalk there's a 
lot of chalk in the gym when we walk around   if you look underneath the sole of your shoe after 
a while it's probably going to be completely white   chalk makes our skin really sticky but not the 
rubber on our shoes so make sure that you clean   your shoes i would say the only exception is 
when uh your shoe is wet then sometimes it   could be good to to dry it up with a little bit of 
chalk but otherwise try to keep your your shoes as   chalk free as possible don't over grip or re-grip 
too much you see a lot of especially beginners   when after they grab a hole they adjust it they 
kind of jank it to to get it a little bit better   but i think in most cases it's better to just 
grab it maybe adjust it one time and then move on   climbing faster i consider myself a pretty fast 
climber but i feel like me included i can also   climb a lot faster i try to tell myself to climb 
faster when i look at people like Adam Ondra and sometimes when you climb fast it's hard to 
to climb everything technically perfect but if   you put up like a side by side comparison you try 
to climb a bowler perfectly and you're trying to   just climb it as fast as possible i think often 
climbing it just as fast as possible will feel   easier because you spend less time on the wall but 
the the best thing is obviously if you can do both   like you climb it perfectly and you climb it fast 
like perfect technique and fast but that's really   hard to do so if i had to choose between the two 
i would just climb uh fast when i started climbing   everything was about climbing as nicely 
as possible doing a lot of drop knees   and trying to stay as close to the wall 
doing everything really controlled but   i feel like the new school technique is to just 
rely more on power and try to climb things quicker next tip is something that you probably 
heard from your climbing coach or whatever   a million times climb with straight arms 
it's super awkward that's much easier i also think that when your fingers get stronger 
it's easier to climb on a straight arm because you   feel more in control so you can let down uh let 
yourself down on a straight arm in the beginning   it feels very unsecure because you don't know 
how much strength you have in the fingers and   your natural reaction will be to like 
kind of bend your arms a little bit   even on moves like dinos and stuff 
it's often beneficial to keep your   arms as straight as possible next step waving 
your hands like this you always want dry as   dry not as dry as possible but you always want 
dry skin so especially if it's hot you'll see   climbers do this so you kind of wave your arms 
and you turn or twist the arm halfway so that you   kind of get as much air as possible you spread 
your fingers out and they will feel a lot drier   another thing that might keep your fingers dry 
is liquid chalk i don't like using liquid chalk   i think it makes it too dry and i also think 
that it wears out my skin quicker if i use   liquid shocks so i personally don't like liquid 
chalk but that i mean that's for you to decide   i would encourage everyone to try it at least and 
see if they like it i have found out that i don't   like it taking care of your skin this is something 
that i could make an entire video on most climbers   are really obsessed with their skin you'll 
see climbers look down at their skin   and kind of try to figure out how much climbing 
is they have left based on how good their skin is   there's a lot of things you can do sandpapering 
the skin is is very popular also make sure that
summary_sections.summary: In this section, the speaker provides 20 tips and tricks for climbers, including filming yourself to analyze technique, cleaning shoes from chalk, not over-gripping or re-gripping too much, climbing faster, climbing with straight arms, and waving hands to dry skin. The speaker also mentions liquid chalk, which they personally do not like, and emphasizes the importance of taking care of one's skin. The speaker suggests that viewers comment if they want more in-depth tutorials on specific topics.

summary_sections.text:
you moisturize the skin a lot of climbers also use 
small blades to cut off like flakes of skin it's   all about keeping the skin as even as possible 
to make it grow as fast as possible so if it's   uneven you try to sandpaper down the thick parts 
so that everything can grow sometimes i also use   something called the antihydrol it's a thing 
that i order from germany i don't know how   healthy that is so i'm not going to recommend 
it to any of you guys but there and there's   also things like rhino skin and i know there's a 
lot of other products as well to keep your skin   dry and dry skin will not wear out as quickly as 
uh as wet skin so trying to keep your skin as dry   as possible while climbing will also make it uh 
more robust so you can climb for longer because i   feel like often that's what prevents us climbers 
from climbing as much as we want is our skin   so trying having good skin care not for your 
face but for your fingers is important i should   also mention that the type of holes that you're 
climbing on really matters when it comes to skin   like these holes are really rough and then you 
have some other holes that are really nice for the   skin and if you want to train for a longer time 
you should definitely choose the bowlers with uh   with with the holes that are not too rough for 
the skin i think it's also important to to know   that you don't need a training program to become 
better uh even among the top climbers the best   climbers in the world everyone trains really 
differently so there's a lot of way to progress   and i think the best way as i've said before 
is just to climb a lot and also to try really   hard when you when you climb tip number 10 is to 
get a hang board you could also get a portable   hangboard we just released this it's on 
rungne.com the link is in the description   uh this you can either use uh separately like 
this you can use it as like sling training and   you have two different grips this way is a little 
bit better this way is a little bit worse this   is obviously a jug and you can also attach them i 
love the sound it makes when you click it together   it has four points of attachment so when you put 
it up and it's uh and it's not split up then it's   super super stable this way you also have a jug 
here uh and also this way the edge is a little bit   more negative so this is a little bit worse and 
there's a little bit of friction inside here too   so it's not uh it's not super slippery there's a 
lot of techniques that climbers use and i think   especially in the beginning it's important to try 
them out even if you don't think they will work   just like drop knees knee bars flagging toe hook 
key hook bicycle pogoing i mean just try out a   bunch of different things because it's always hard 
to know what technique to apply to a new problem   if you haven't climbed it before and i think just 
like instinctively uh realizing what you have   to do it just comes with practice but the more 
you try different things like techniques in the   beginning the easier it's gonna get to immediately 
know what technique uh to use on a on a new   problem it's better to try one hundred percent 
one time than to try fifty percent two times i   always go for high quality you have to try really 
hard and fail that's the only way that the body   is gonna improve and become stronger and for high 
quality you also you can't be afraid of failing   in the gym um i know it's uh for me included 
it's sometimes you feel like people watching you   uh you're afraid of making of looking dumb and 
failing in public the gyms are really crowded   everyone's watching but i think it's important 
not to care too much about failing i mean failing   is definitely part of any climber's process if 
you don't fail you don't try hard enough for   most climbers failing is like 90 percent and maybe 
not for Alex Honnold because he's free soloing so   uh he can't fail but for the rest of us 
failing is definitely a big part of climbing   okay the next tip is to find a shoe that fits you 
really well and the best way to do that is go to   like a shoe demo or go to a climbing shop that has 
like a little climbing wall or somewhere where you   can try out the shoes uh because the shoe will 
feel very different when you put it on and when   you're actually climbing with it when you put 
like pressure on the different parts of the shoe   so make sure that you can actually try out 
the shoes before deciding on a shoe and we   all have like our feet are very different so it's 
important that you find a shoe that fits your foot   so if i tell you that a shoe is really good for me 
it doesn't necessarily mean that it's good for you   but there are definitely some good and some bad 
shoes out there okay the next uh tip is also a
summary_sections.summary: In this section, the speaker gives tips for maintaining and improving climbing skills, including moisturizing and taking care of the skin, using specific products to keep the skin dry, and choosing the right type of climbing holes. The speaker also recommends trying out different techniques and not being afraid to fail in order to improve, as well as finding a shoe that fits well through trying them out at demos or climbing shops. The speaker also promotes a portable hangboard product and emphasizes the importance of climbing frequently and challenging oneself.

summary_sections.text:
climbing skin related tip it's to wash off the 
chalk after climbing immediately because the skin   will not start growing until you get the chalk off 
so make sure that you wash your hands immediately   after climbing so that the healing process of the 
skin can start as quickly as possible okay so the   next tip is to make bowlers once in a while on 
a wall like the one behind me a case wall also   called a spray wall it's just full of holes and 
you decide what holes to use for your hands and   for your feet i think it's very good for memory 
but also to understand how to move on the wall   and how root setters think you know it's it's 
not only the size of the holes and the distance   between holes that make a roller hard it's more 
complex than that and i think making bowlers on   a wall like this will give you a much better 
understanding of not only how the roots are   think but also just how the body works and how 
like different moves work so definitely encourage   everyone to to do this once in a while it's 
probably not as fun as like regular baldering just   walking around having a lot of preset bowlers it's 
kind of a everything back in the days everything   used to be like this ever like you you had to 
make your own problems with friends uh you had   to remember those problems for the next session 
but nowadays uh everything is just preset in   colors on big walls that they change out 
often my next step is to train more core   i think a lot of us we kind of stop training when 
our skin and fingers and arms feel worked it feels   like you can't climb anymore but i think training 
a little bit more core after that because core is   just completely different you can train a lot more 
core even when your fingers and arms are finished   so training more core at the end of the session 
i think would benefit any climber uh the next tip   probably comes as a surprise to most of you but 
it's to warm up i i joke about this but i feel bad   for joking about it it's also very personal 
how much warming up your body needs but i think   you should definitely warm up for 20 minutes to 
half an hour to to just prevent injuries and to   also get your body ready to just pull really hard 
i've always been really bad at warming up and it's   definitely something that i should become better 
at now that i'm getting older definitely warm up   find a routine that works for you there's a lot of 
tutorials on this on on youtube but again i think   it's important to find a warm-up routine that 
works for you it's i think in general training and   also dieting and everything it's it's a lot more 
personal than we think so um you should always   try to find a thing experiment a little bit and 
try to find things that work for you not listen   blindly to what other people have to say um 
the next thing is dieting it's something that   i haven't talked so much about on this channel 
but of course weight is important in climbing   unfortunately i would say because i don't know 
it's something that a lot of climbers struggle   with and i feel like sometimes losing weight 
uh is like a short-term solution it's uh it's   like a shortcut i don't know i would not encourage 
anyone to to really go on a diet if it's not for   for health reasons right now i'm trying to 
actually gain a little bit of weight because   i i was a little bit lighter and i don't 
know i feel like my mood and everything my   like the quality of life goes down and for me 
it's not worth it now that i'm not a professional   anymore it's definitely if you have a weight 
to lose and you feel like you can do it in a   healthy way then then it's it could be a good 
thing because weight is important in climbing   but at the same time i would also uh warn 
you against like dieting too hard and   i think it's a rabbit hole that a lot of people 
a lot of climbers uh fall into and never get out   of so like a lot of climbers have problems with 
eating disorders i've had it as well uh in my   in my youth and uh i would also encourage 
people to to look around and try to try to see   uh try to help other people with eating disorders 
because it's a serious problem in climbing and   not only in climbing but everywhere right now and 
uh yeah so that's why i don't want to talk about   uh too much about like dieting and food and 
eating tips and stuff on this channel because   i'm not a an expert when it comes to that 
and yeah i know how how dangerous it can be   so so the next tip is to not respect higher grades 
i think a lot of people have too much respect they
summary_sections.summary: In this section, the speaker gives five tips for climbing, including washing off chalk to promote skin healing, practicing on spray walls to understand movement and root setters, training core after finger and arm fatigue, warming up for 20-30 minutes to prevent injury, and cautioning against excessive dieting and respecting higher grades. The speaker also acknowledges the personal nature of training and encourages experimentation to find what works best for each individual. They also highlight the issue of eating disorders in climbing and encourage support for those struggling with them.

summary_sections.summary: In this section, the speaker encourages viewers to not be intimidated by grades and to instead try anything they like. They suggest that trying a difficult challenge, like a hard bowling move, can be beneficial even if you don't succeed. The speaker emphasizes that grades are just made up numbers and won't necessarily do you any favors. They end by asking for feedback and suggesting that they may do more videos on tips and tricks.

l6xfFYZAyns.summary_all: In this video, businesses are using feature stores to transform raw data into useful features for machine learning models. This allows for data to be pulled from various sources and stored in a central location for easy access, increasing productivity. Feature stores also provide data governance and monitoring capabilities to track the distribution of features over time and discover problems. Overall, a feature store is a powerful tool within the machine learning stack.

summary_sections.text: okay so you have a bunch of raw data that you need to make useful but wrangling that data can be challenging requiring expertise computational resources and a lot of work to set up to take that burden off the data scientists businesses are now using a tool called a feature store to help them not only store their data but also transform it into useful features that machine learning models can use directly to make predictions that solve problems that raw data is typically coming from various data sources of various types structured unstructured streaming batch real time it all needs to get pulled and stored somewhere that somewhere can be a feature store and the feature store then takes that raw data and makes it available for consumption and in some implementations provides feature pipelines that can transform that data the pipelines produce process features that can be used for both online and offline environments those process features are then used by data scientists and ml engineers to produce high quality predictive models the outputs of those models then get used to solve a plethora of business problems for end users feature stores allow data scientists to work more efficiently by allowing the reuse and sharing of features so that other teams can use them too and thereby increase their own productivity since they don't have to do it from scratch this helps make the most out of the data and makes things better for data scientists by providing solutions to common data engineering problems feature stores can also provide data governance through feature lineage and versioning those with monitoring capabilities allow the business to track the distribution of their features over time and discover problems such as training serving sku or concept drift overall a feature store functions as a powerful interface between your data and your models and is a powerful tool within the mlap stack you
summary_sections.summary: In this section, the speaker explains how businesses are using feature stores to transform raw data into useful features for machine learning models. Feature stores allow data to be pulled from various sources and stored in a central location for easy access. This helps data scientists work more efficiently by allowing them to reuse and share features, increasing productivity. Feature stores also provide data governance and monitoring capabilities to track the distribution of features over time and discover problems. Overall, a feature store is a powerful tool within the machine learning stack.

KEtmZ8uMiWI.summary_all: In this video, the need for energy and various sources of energy are discussed. The possibility of using children as an energy source is humorously suggested. The theory of piezoelectricity and its potential for energy conversion is explored, including its advantages of self-powering capabilities. The limitations of sound energy harvesting are acknowledged, and using vibrations from the environment is suggested. The section ends with a reflection on the state of the planet and the future of energy.

summary_sections.text:
The world needs energy. Well, I'm not really teaching you anything, this is not news. The skyrocketing development of humankind comes largely thanks to its capacity to produce, to stock and to use energy in order to accomplish things impossible for the body alone. And nowadays, when one speak about "access to energy", one talks about this gesture. One simple gesture which grants everyone electricity, powering the majority of the devices around us including the ones used to make this video or to allow you to look at it while you're on the toilet. Yes but where does electricty comes from ? Because we didn't answer anythi... Well ! We can indeed ask ourself this question given the fact that "natural" electricity is 
extremely rare and instable just like lightning for example. What am I doing here ? (This is the old set of an famous french tv show about science) Ha ! That's better (This is the classic set of the channel, black bg) ! So we can't rely on natural sources of electricity to ensure the massive and continuous production we need The solution, since we can't create energy from nothing, is to take another energy and to convert it. Solar energy, wind energy, nuclear energy, hydroelectric energy, fossil fuels or even biomass are the main forms of energy used and transformed into electrical energy. In addition, one must not forget chemical batteries for stocking energy but in other words: one can say we're pretty good with electrical energy... The issue is the energy demand is still rising. One need to consume more, to grow faster and it's not without additional energy
but also additional pollution Meanwhile, temperatures and oceans are rising
biodiversity is shrinking and even if we're still looking a infinite, non-polluting form of energy we're realizing that it won't exist and that we are in big train which is speeding up into the wall of extinction. “It is my professional opinion that now is the time to PANIC.” This is Boo. Boo is a child and like Nutella once said in a french ad Children needs energy. In other words, a child contains energy. Thus one might consider exploiting children as a energy source. And of course, those people are monsters ... I mean litteraly. The future is bright at Monsters, Inc! We power your car, we warm your home, we light your city! Warefuly matching every child to their ideal monster, to produce superior scream. Refined into clean, dependable energy. Every time you turn something on, Monsters, Inc is there. We're working for a better tomorrow, today ! We're Monsters, Incorporated, we scare because we care. … producing electricity with children's screams … ... ok why not. (On this part, the words and sentences are synchronized to the music, so it may pass very quickly) What is a scream ? We need to know that ! A scream is basically noise. So what is noise ? Well, it's sound !
It may be obvious for you, but I think we need to look at the basic vocabulary
before diving into the physics of sounds, screams ... and roars. To generate a sound, air molecules vibrate quickly and transmit this vibration
to one another, in fact a sound is a mechanical longitudinal wave. It means that molecules moves in the same direction as the direction of propagation of the wave and since they all take back their initial position after the wave we call that "energy transportation without matter transportation". We just need to get that energy. To make e-lec-tri-ci-ty, weeeeeeeeeeeeeellll we need to convert the mechanical energy "inside" the sound wave into electrical energy. As a matter of fact, we do that all the time 
and even right now ! all sounds system are constantly converting an electrical signal into sound waves, in one way or the other. Such as the microphones the speakers, the record players, … I don't have any examples anymore but that's ok we understand now that the door has to be like a mic. Of course, all of this must be invisible for the human world. To not raise any suspicion, we can't change the look of the doors. And as we're looking to get the maximum of energy out the the sound and so getting the wave on the entire surface of the door, an interesting solution would be to find a material in which we could make the doors. A special material which could convert mechanical vibrations into electricity. And this material exists and it's called a piezoelectric. It's pretty basic: you squish it, it zaps you. Okay so let's calm down and let's talk piezoelectricity. As we saw it, a piezoelectric has the weird feature of generating an
electrical charge when you apply to it a mechanical force but this also works in reverse : it generates a mechanical strain under an electrical field. It may sound a bit highbrow but piezoelectrics are very common and we can find them in a variety of daily-life objects. For example:
summary_sections.summary: In this section, the video discusses the need for energy and the various sources of energy that can be converted into electrical energy. However, the demand for energy is still increasing, leading to additional pollution and environmental issues. The video then humorously suggests using children as an energy source, before delving into the science of sound and how it can be converted into electrical energy using piezoelectric materials. Piezoelectric materials generate an electrical charge when a mechanical force is applied to them and are commonly found in daily-life objects.

summary_sections.text:
An individual finds himself facing a satanic symbol.
(This is the logo of a really shitty but succesful tv show in France) Then, he grabs his piezo lighter in his pocket. By pushing the button, he compresses the piezo crystal hidden inside, creating a electrical surcharge dissipated as a small spark, lighting up the flame. Armed qith the malicious power of fire, the man can burn the evil on this land and make the world a better place. Same thing for a gas cooker ! I like the piezoelectric theory for several reasons. Firstly, beyond lighters, it's already used for sound systems such as mics and speakers, but very very thin. It seems relevant for our problem: we just have to cover the door with some piezo overlay and we would have our energy converter. The other advantage is that, the energy collection is integrated in the door, it could power itself ! Thus explaining how Boo's laugh can activate the doors in the epic third act of the movie, without being connected to the energy network. Hmm yes … because we only talked about screams for now but the fact that "laugh is 10 times more powerful than scream" is given to us at the end of the movie. So why ? Someone ? A human doesn't produce pure sounds but modulated ones. One doesn't generate continuous sounds, one emits sound intensity spikes quickly. In the case of a speech or a lauch, it is approximately 3-4 spikes a second. In 2015, a team of researchers, found that during a scream our vocal chords enter
a particular vibration regime provoking a very quick modulation of of the voice between 30 to 150 times a second, a phenomenon called roughness. Let's hear an example : Here is a continuous tone : and now the same tone but modulated to become rough. Aaaaaaaaah We could imagine that the vibration of the doors depends on this modulation frequency and a door would resonate for the low frequency of a laugh and not so much for a rough scream. Explaing how we harvest more energy with laughs! Then, we may discuss the inconsistencies of this theory with other facts in the movie: why Boo can power doors but also overpower the all network, how to stock scream in bottles then ? but one must know when to stop making weird hypothesis to explain imaginary things. That's it. I'm out of ideas. Because Monsters Incorporated is like dragons, magic or happy marriage it only exists in movies. Sorry. Well, it is possible to harvest sound energy, and with piezoelectrics, but it is so bad. Even with a sound power that would kill a bird, we could only harvest something like 0.01W/m². For comparison, wind energy is 200 times more effective and solar energy is 20 000 times more effective. "Human energies, 200 to 20000 times better !" But as we explained, harvesting sound energy is more about harvesting mechanical energy from vibrations than sound itself, and with piezoelectricity we could do better than lighters. By using the vibrations of the environment after the passing of a train or the footsteps of people in a mall, we might generate enough electricity to charge small devices or power signposts. One could also imagine small connected devices such as a watch or earphones which would charge thanks to our moves. However with that idea, we only made the stupid snickers that light up when you walk ... but there is potential ! To conclude, we will never charge our phones with a scream, good news actually, and harvesting children screams wouldn't save us from the energy crisis, we're still in a sh*tty situation. I'm sorry this conclusion is a bit funk depression. Wait no I meant full depression ... What am I saying ? funk depression? ... funk dep... funk depression! We screwed the planet! Far right politicians going strong all over the world ... Future nice vibes at the frontier! I love water, in 20 years it will be gone. See you next time, unless I die first, then there won't be a next time! Alright, Mr Bile, is it?
summary_sections.summary: In this section, the speaker discusses the theory of piezoelectricity and its potential for energy conversion. They explain how it works and its advantages, such as self-powering capabilities. The speaker then explores how the theory could explain the energy collection in the doors in the movie Monsters Inc., based on the modulation frequency of sound. However, the speaker acknowledges the limitations of sound energy harvesting and suggests using vibrations from the environment instead. The section concludes with a somber reflection on the state of the planet and the future of energy.

bfihB2wkIO8.summary_all: In this video, Madame Kingsiam Gloss discusses her thesis on enhancing concrete's self-healing properties by using crystalline additives, expansive agents, and superabsorbent polymers. She tests various combinations of these products to determine the best solution. Madame Kingsiam Gloss conducts experiments on concrete specimens and concludes that self-healing concrete with additives is a promising solution for reducing repair costs, increasing the lifespan of structures, and improving road safety.

summary_sections.text: notre troisième participante et madame king siam gloss le titre long de sa thèse et effet des ajouts cristallin en combinaison avec des agents expansif et des polymères superabsorbants sur l'auto cicatrisation des bétons et le titre vulgariser béton autocicatrisant à l'aide de différents âges directeur jean philippe charron bonjour à tous alors à main levée qui est tombé à cause du verglas cet hiver moi aussi je suis même tombé plusieurs fois mais heureusement sans me faire mal par contre j'ai une amie qui a glissé il ya quelques semaines est elle tombée s est cassé le poignet c'est douloureux mais il n'y a pas que nous qui subissons les affres de l'hiver nos structures en béton en pâtissent aussi en amérique du nord 40% des ponts sont déficients et des sommes astronomiques sont dépensés chaque année pour l'heure pour leur réparation la cause la présence de fissures qui réduisent la durabilité des ouvrages en béton en laissant entrer des agents agressif comme les cld verglaçants mais au fait comment fait-on du béton la recette est simple prenez du sable de la pierre du ciment rajouter de l'eau et des adjuvants et vous obtiendrez un beau mélange de béton comme le corps humain le béton à une certaine capacité d'auto cicatrisation naturelle en fait les grains de ciment qui n'ont pas encore réagi dans le coeur du béton vont s'hydrater avec l'eau qui va pénétrer dans la fissure et savent à la colmater en format en déshydrate mais en fait cette capacité de cicatrisation naturelle elle est vraiment minime et donc pour l'augmenter on peut en incorporer au mélange un ingrédient secret des ajouts dans mon projet je vais utiliser différents produits qu'on appelle à jouques ritalin agents expansif et polymères super absorbants en gros ce sont des poudres et comme pour des épices je cherche à déterminer la meilleure combinaison portée munir le béton le but savoureux et qui a le meilleur potentiel de cicatrisation pour évaluer cette pensée capacité de cicatrisation la méthologie consiste à préférer des spécimens de béton et à les soumettre à différentes conditions d'exposition pardon dans l'eau dans l'air et j'ai aussi entre poser quelques spécimens à l'extérieur dans des sorte d'enclos pour lapins pour voir si en situation réelle on observe de la cicatrisation via des mesures de perméabilité et de l'analyse de photos au microscope je peux évaluer le potentiel de cicatrisation des différents mélanges que je vais réaliser par exemple sur la photo comme vous pouvez le voir c'est une fissure qui après un mois sous ios est complètement refermée en conclusion le béton autocicatrisant autocicatrisant à l'aide d'ajouts est une solution prometteuse qui s'inscrit dans une démarche de développement durable mes travaux vont permettre de réduire les coûts de réparation d'augmenter la durée de vie des structures et de réduire les nuisances aux usagers c'est à dire réduire le nombre de cônes orange sur les routes à summary_sections.summary: In this section, Madame Kingsiam Gloss discusses her thesis on the use of crystalline additives, expansive agents, and superabsorbent polymers to improve the self-healing properties of concrete. She explains that concrete has a natural ability to self-heal, but it is limited, and her research aims to enhance this capability. Madame Kingsiam Gloss uses various products to determine the best combination for improving concrete's self-healing potential. She conducts tests on concrete specimens under different conditions to evaluate their healing capacity and concludes that self-healing concrete with additives is a promising solution for reducing repair costs, increasing the lifespan of structures, and improving road safety.

GFMeuSIhIYg.summary_all: In this video, Brian Chesky talks about his experience staying in an Airbnb in Harlem and his origin story, including the creation of the first Airbnb. He discusses the challenges of raising capital and the importance of having a unique insight when starting a company. Chesky also talks about the pushback from stakeholders and how Airbnb has had to partner with cities to come to a resolution. Lastly, he discusses Airbnb's approach to regulating home-sharing and their goal to become a one-stop-shop for experiences.

summary_sections.summary: In this section, Brian Chesky talks about staying in an Airbnb in Harlem with interior designer hosts and cooking with his girlfriend. He discusses his origin story, growing up with social worker parents and pursuing a career in art despite his mother's advice to choose a job with better pay. Chesky describes how his entrepreneurial journey started with a friend from Rhode Island School of Design and the creation of the first Airbnb, which started as a bed and breakfast during a design conference in San Francisco. The success of the idea led to the formation of the company and its growth to over 160 million guests today.

summary_sections.summary: In this section, Brian Chesky, co-founder of Airbnb, talks about the early days of the company and how difficult it was to raise capital. People thought the idea of strangers staying with other strangers was crazy, and investors were hesitant to fund the company. Chesky and his co-founder ended up funding the company themselves using credit cards and even created a cereal business to make money. Chesky believes that startups today are over capitalized and that you don't need millions of dollars to start an idea.

have to know something no one else knows about your business otherwise why are you doing it and why doesn't already exist so the big question is what do you know that no one else knows about your business you need to have a unique insight and we had a very simple unique insight it was totally by happenstance in other words we randomly rented her home one weekend and so our unique insight was it's actually not weird for stranger to stay of those strangers and you can make a bunch of money and the people who travel there can save money have an amazing experience if people could just experience what we experienced that one weekend this would be an idea that would spread on the world and again maybe thousands of people one day would use Airbnb and that was our you insight and so summary_sections.summary: In this section, Airbnb co-founder, Brian Chesky, discusses the importance of having a unique insight when starting a company and how their insight was the idea that it's not weird for strangers to stay with strangers and make money. He also talks about the challenges they faced as disruptors and the pushback from stakeholders, particularly in markets where short-term rentals violate local laws. Chesky explains how they had to change their approach and partner with cities to come to a resolution, resulting in agreements with 200 cities worldwide. He also discusses the challenges they faced in New York City, where landlords were taking units off the market, and how they have had to play catch-up to address these issues.

summary_sections.summary: In this section, Airbnb CEO talks about their approach to regulating home-sharing and their new "friendly neighbor landlord program." He also discusses the importance of putting the best people on new projects and constantly testing. He emphasizes the need to focus on creating something that people want, rather than just a revenue generator. The company's goal for the next 10 years is to sell end-to-end trips and to become a one-stop-shop for experiences.
